article.title: Nucleosynthesis in 2D Core-Collapse Supernovae of 11.2 and 17.0 M$_{\odot }$ Progenitors: Implications for Mo and Ru Production

choices: The evolution of the shock wave in the 11.2 M progenitor over time.
The distribution of nickel-56 in the ejecta of the 11.2 M progenitor.
The evolution of temperature and electron fraction for tracer particles in the 11.2 M progenitor CCSN simulation.
The comparison of nucleosynthesis yields between 11.2 M and 17.0 M progenitors.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between Figure 1 and Figure 2?
choices: Figure 2 shows the evolution of temperature and electron fraction in a 17.0 M progenitor CCSN simulation.
Figure 2 focuses on the production of molybdenum and ruthenium isotopes.
Figure 2 depicts the formation of presolar grains in the ejecta.
Figure 2 compares the results of different ejection criteria.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information is presented in Figure 3?
choices: The distribution of tracer particles according to their peak temperatures.
The abundance ratios of molybdenum and ruthenium isotopes in presolar grains.
The isotopic [X/Fe] distribution in the ejecta of the 11.2 and 17.0 M progenitors after decay to stability.
The neutrino luminosities and average energies as a function of time.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this equation represent? (etot = eth + v²/2 + φ)
choices: The electron fraction in the neutrino-driven wind.
The specific total energy of a particle in a supernova simulation.
The production rate of molybdenum isotopes in neutron-rich conditions.
The ratio of neutrino luminosities to average energies.
